Title: Milestone 0: Project Foundation & Setup
Description & Technical Notes: Establish a professional, reproducible development environment. This milestone is about building the workshop before you build the product.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): Critical

Title: Environment Setup
Description & Technical Notes: Create the repository and a containerized local development environment for consistency.
Learning Objective: Understand the importance of a clean, version-controlled, and reproducible developer setup.
Deliverable: A new GitHub repository and a working local Docker environment.

Title: Initialize Git Repository
Description & Technical Notes: Create a GitHub repository. Add a README.md, a comprehensive .gitignore for Python/Solidity, and the core project directories: /contracts, /backend, /scripts, /tests, /docs.
Learning Objective: Learn the fundamentals of version control with Git and standard project structuring.
Deliverable: A new public GitHub repository containing the specified files and folder structure.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): The repository exists and is accessible online. The main branch contains the correct folder structure.

Title: Install Core Tooling
Description & Technical Notes: Install Foundry for smart contract development. Install Python and create a `requirements.txt` file for the backend. Add `web3.py` and `fastapi` to start.
Learning Objective: Gain familiarity with the core tooling for Solidity and Python development.
Deliverable: Successful version checks for `forge` and `python` in the terminal.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): `forge --version`, `python --version`, and `pip install -r requirements.txt` all execute without errors.

Title: Containerize Services with Docker Compose
Description & Technical Notes: Create a `docker-compose.yml` file to define and link services for a PostgreSQL database and an Anvil testnet node. This allows the entire dev environment to start with one command.
Learning Objective: Understand how Docker Compose orchestrates multi-service local development environments.
Deliverable: A `docker-compose.yml` file in the root directory.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): Running `docker-compose up` successfully starts both a PostgreSQL container and an Anvil container, with logs visible for both.

Title: Milestone 1: End-to-End Core Logic
Description & Technical Notes: Prove the core cryptographic concept by connecting an off-chain script to an on-chain smart contract. This is the highest-risk and most novel part of the system.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): Critical

Title: Implement BatchRegistry Contract
Description & Technical Notes: Develop the primary smart contract responsible for storing Merkle root commitments, which acts as the on-chain anchor of trust.
Learning Objective: Master the fundamentals of smart contract development, security, and Test-Driven Development (TDD) with Foundry.
Deliverable: A secure, tested, and well-documented `BatchRegistry.sol` contract.

Title: Research OpenZeppelin AccessControl
Description & Technical Notes: Read the official OpenZeppelin documentation for `AccessControl.sol`. Understand how roles are defined, granted, and checked with the `onlyRole` modifier.
Learning Objective: Build the habit of reading technical documentation before implementing, a critical engineering skill.
Deliverable: A few bullet points in a personal log summarizing what `AccessControl` does and why it's useful.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): You can explain what `DEFAULT_ADMIN_ROLE` and `keccak256("OPERATOR_ROLE")` do.

Title: Implement BatchRegistry.sol Structure
Description & Technical Notes: Create `contracts/BatchRegistry.sol`. Import `AccessControl.sol` and `ReentrancyGuard.sol`. Define state variables and the `OPERATOR_ROLE` constant as per the architecture.
Learning Objective: Learn basic Solidity syntax, state management, and how to import external dependencies.
Deliverable: A `BatchRegistry.sol` file that compiles successfully.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): The command `forge build` executes without any compiler errors.

Title: Write Failing Test for commitBatch
Description & Technical Notes: In `tests/BatchRegistry.t.sol`, write a test for the `commitBatch` function *before* implementing it. The test should fail because the function doesn't exist yet.
Learning Objective: Understand the "Red" step of the Red-Green-Refactor TDD cycle.
Deliverable: A new test file with a single, failing test case.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): Running `forge test` shows one test failing as expected.

Title: Implement commitBatch Function
Description & Technical Notes: Implement the `commitBatch` function with the full signature. Use the `onlyRole` modifier. The logic should store the Merkle root and emit the `BatchCommitted` event.
Learning Objective: Understand the "Green" step of TDD by writing the minimum code to make a failing test pass.
Deliverable: The implementation of the `commitBatch` function inside `BatchRegistry.sol`.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): The previously failing test from M1.1.2 now passes. The `forge test` command shows 1 passing test.

Title: Test Access Control Rejection
Description & Technical Notes: Write a new test (`test_Revert_When_NotOperator`) that uses `vm.prank` and `vm.expectRevert` to prove that calls from non-operator accounts fail as expected.
Learning Objective: Learn how to test for security rules and failure cases, which is as important as testing for success.
Deliverable: A new passing test case in `BatchRegistry.t.sol`.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): `forge test` shows 2 passing tests.

Title: Build Off-Chain Merkle & Connection Scripts
Description & Technical Notes: Create the Python scripts that will build the Merkle tree and send the transaction to the smart contract, bridging the off-chain and on-chain worlds.
Learning Objective: Learn how a backend application interacts with a smart contract using libraries and RPC connections.
Deliverable: Two Python scripts: one for building a Merkle tree, one for sending a transaction.

Title: Implement Merkle Tree Builder Script
Description & Technical Notes: Create `scripts/merkle_builder.py`. Use a library like `pymerkle` to take a list of applicant data, serialize it according to the canonical format, build a tree, and return the root.
Learning Objective: Learn the practical application of cryptographic primitives like hash functions and Merkle trees.
Deliverable: A Python function `generate_merkle_root(applicants)` that returns a hex string.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): The function produces a predictable Merkle root for a given input list, verifiable with an online tool.

Title: Implement Blockchain Transaction Script
Description & Technical Notes: Create `scripts/commit_batch.py`. Use `web3.py` to connect to the local Anvil node. It should load the contract ABI, address, and an operator private key (from a `.env` file) to call the `commitBatch` function.
Learning Objective: Learn how to send transactions to a blockchain, including handling contract ABIs, addresses, and private keys for signing.
Deliverable: A runnable Python script that sends a transaction.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): Running `python scripts/commit_batch.py` prints a transaction hash and the `BatchCommitted` event is visible in the Anvil console logs.

Title: Milestone 2: Minimum Viable Product (MVP)
Description & Technical Notes: Build the full application loop: a backend API for data ingestion, a database for storage, an indexer to sync state, and a simple UI for users to see the results.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): Critical

Title: Build Backend API & Database
Description & Technical Notes: Create a FastAPI server to handle applicant data. This is the primary entry point for operators into the system.
Learning Objective: Learn the fundamentals of API design, database modeling with an ORM, and secure data handling.
Deliverable: A functional FastAPI application with endpoints for managing applicants and batches.

Title: Design & Implement DB Schema with ORM
Description & Technical Notes: In `backend/models.py`, use SQLAlchemy to define Python classes for the `applicants`, `batches`, and `leaves` tables. Create a script to initialize the database schema.
Learning Objective: Understand how Object-Relational Mapping (ORM) abstracts raw SQL and helps maintain a consistent data model in code.
Deliverable: Python files defining the database models (`models.py`).
Acceptance Criteria (AC): The script runs and successfully creates the tables in the PostgreSQL database.

Title: Implement Secure Applicant Ingestion API
Description & Technical Notes: Create a `POST /v1/applicants` endpoint in FastAPI. Use a Pydantic model for request body validation. The endpoint logic will hash the unique ID and store the data in the `applicants` table.
Learning Objective: Learn how modern web frameworks use data validation and how to handle sensitive data by hashing identifiers.
Deliverable: A new endpoint in `backend/main.py`.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): Sending a `POST` request with a valid JSON body to the endpoint returns a `201 Created` status.

Title: Implement Batch Creation API
Description & Technical Notes: Create a `POST /v1/batches` endpoint. This endpoint will fetch eligible applicants from the DB and trigger the (now refactored) `commit_batch` logic from M1.2.2.
Learning Objective: Learn to compose existing services (DB access, blockchain script) into a single API endpoint.
Deliverable: A new endpoint in `backend/main.py`.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): Calling this endpoint successfully commits a new batch to the blockchain using data pulled from the database.

Title: Develop the Blockchain Indexer
Description & Technical Notes: Create the service that listens for on-chain events and populates the database, making on-chain data queryable and available to the frontend.
Learning Objective: Learn about event-driven architecture and the critical role of indexers in making dApp data useful.
Deliverable: A standalone Python service that syncs blockchain events to the database.

Title: Implement Event Listener
Description & Technical Notes: Create `indexer/listener.py`. Use `web3.py`'s WebSocketProvider to subscribe to `BatchCommitted` events. On receipt, the listener should simply log the full event data.
Learning Objective: Learn how to create a persistent connection to a blockchain node to listen for real-time events.
Deliverable: A Python script that can run as a background service.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): When a new batch is committed, the indexer process prints the raw event data to its console within seconds.

Title: Implement Batch Verification Logic
Description & Technical Notes: When the indexer receives an event, it must fetch the corresponding applicant data, re-compute the Merkle root, and confirm it matches the root from the on-chain event.
Learning Objective: Learn the importance of the "trust but verify" principle in decentralized systems. The indexer must act as an independent auditor.
Deliverable: A verification function `verify_batch(event_data)` within the indexer.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): The function returns `True` for a valid batch and `False` for a batch with a mismatched root, logging the outcome.

Title: Implement DB Ingestion Logic
Description & Technical Notes: If batch verification succeeds, the indexer must write the batch and leaf data to the `batches` and `leaves` tables within an atomic database transaction.
Learning Objective: Learn how to use database transactions to ensure data consistency, especially in an asynchronous, event-driven system.
Deliverable: A database function `save_verified_batch(...)` used by the indexer.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): After a successful batch commit, the `batches` and `leaves` tables are correctly populated. No partial data is ever written.

Title: Build Frontend User Interfaces
Description & Technical Notes: Create a simple UI for public transparency and for applicants to check their status. This makes the system's promises tangible to end-users.
Learning Objective: Learn the basics of a modern frontend framework and how it consumes data from a backend API to build a user experience.
Deliverable: A simple, single-page web application (SPA).

Title: Implement Indexer API for Frontend
Description & Technical Notes: Create new read-only endpoints in the FastAPI backend (e.g., `GET /v1/batches`, `GET /v1/applicants/{hash}/status`) that serve data from the indexer's database.
Learning Objective: Learn how to design and build read-only API endpoints optimized for consumption by a user interface.
Deliverable: New GET endpoints in `backend/main.py`.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): Accessing these endpoints in a browser or with `curl` returns correctly formatted JSON data from the database.

Title: Build Public Explorer UI
Description & Technical Notes: Using React or Vue, create a page that calls the `GET /v1/batches` endpoint and displays a table of all committed batches.
Learning Objective: Learn how to fetch data in a frontend application and render it as a dynamic list.
Deliverable: A UI component that displays a list of batches. A screenshot of the working UI.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): The web application loads and displays a list of batches fetched from the backend API.

Title: Build Applicant Status Portal UI
Description & Technical Notes: Create a page with an input box. A user can enter their applicant hash, and the UI will call the status endpoint to display their batch ID and position.
Learning Objective: Learn how to handle user input and display conditional data in a frontend application.
Deliverable: A UI component for status lookup. A screenshot showing a successful lookup.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): An applicant can enter their hash, click a button, and see their correct status displayed on the page.

Title: Milestone 3: Advanced Topics & Documentation
Description & Technical Notes: Go beyond the MVP to explore production-level concepts. The focus is on research and documentation, demonstrating a mature understanding of real-world system architecture.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): Medium

Title: Research & Document Production Concepts
Description & Technical Notes: Formalize your learnings in high-quality documentation. This is where you demonstrate that you understand the path from your prototype to a production-ready system.
Learning Objective: Learn to communicate complex technical concepts clearly and concisely, a crucial skill for senior engineers.
Deliverable: A `/docs` directory populated with professional-quality Markdown documents.

Title: Write Project Architecture Document
Description & Technical Notes: Create `docs/architecture.md`. Based on the original proposal and your implementation, create your own diagrams (e.g., using Mermaid.js or an online tool) and explanations for how the system works.
Learning Objective: Learn to synthesize and document a complete system architecture.
Deliverable: A detailed `architecture.md` file with at least one system diagram.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): The document clearly explains each component, the data flows, and the rationale behind key design choices.

Title: Write Security & Governance Model
Description & Technical Notes: Create `docs/security.md`. Explain the role of KMS/HSM for production key management and on-chain governance (e.g., a Gnosis Safe) for contract upgrades. Research and describe at least two potential smart contract vulnerabilities and how your design mitigates them.
Learning Objective: Learn to think adversarially and understand the security and governance models required for real-world dApps.
Deliverable: A `security.md` file outlining threats, mitigations, and governance strategies.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): The document outlines key security threats and how production-grade tools and practices would mitigate them.

Title: Write Scalability Analysis
Description & Technical Notes: Create `docs/scalability.md`. Write a script to populate your DB with 1 million synthetic `leaves`. Benchmark the applicant lookup query time. Propose and explain a specific scaling strategy (e.g., PostgreSQL partitioning by `wilayaCode`).
Learning Objective: Learn how to benchmark a system, identify potential bottlenecks, and make data-driven decisions about scaling.
Deliverable: A `scalability.md` document with benchmark results and a scaling proposal.
Acceptance Criteria (AC): The document includes performance numbers (e.g., query latency) and a well-reasoned proposal for handling national-level scale.
